The authors acknowledge that this ethical approach also prioritizes utility over justice, the principle that treatments be distributed equally among patient groups. Emerging data suggest that members of socioeconomically disadvantaged communities have a diminished ability to socially distance due to increased use of public transportation, crowded housing conditions, and employment in “essential” jobs that require in-person attendance.

77 These communities also have a greater prevalence of comorbid conditions associated with worse outcomes in COVID-19.
77 A utilitarian approach to CPR or ECMO has the potential to perpetuate these disparities by withholding life-saving therapies from vulnerable populations,
78 but this may be unavoidable in an infectious epidemic. The principle of distributive justice may be better applied by allocating healthcare resources to increase testing, surveillance, and early treatment in disadvantaged communities before their members are hospitalized.
